Wendigo1,"2019-11-11T01:36:04.95Z","Is that street legal?","

For my latest review, I have
column2: 75891-1: Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 Race Car. Is this another track dweller that can&#39
column3: t transition to the street? We&#39

column1: Minifigure and scenery: This comes with a standard Speed Champions minifigure: yellow head, plain legs, single color helmet, and custom torso. Lame. The non-car build is a quick fuel can, with a harpoon gun handle as the fuel spigot. I really like the clever use of the 2x4 round bricks and inverted 2x4
column2: round tile to make the can portion. Combined with the 1x1&nbsp
column3: block with stud extra stud face as the fuel point on the vehicle is a great touch.&nbsp

column1: Build: This was a bit more intricate than I expected for a Speed Champions build, but it works really well to represent the Camaro. The rear assembly uses the tile lock in trick I'
column2: ve seen on other Speed Champions sets. It really makes the back of the car very sturdy. Additionally, the build gives the car an aggressive angled appearance, with the rear tires seemingly lifting the back end up. It&#39
column3: s a great optical illusion. The build has a clever build on the back slope of the passenger compartment, giving the appearance of a curve with straight pieces. Inside the compartment is a racing harness built with robot arms, handlebars and a plain rod. It&#39
column4: s neat and functional, but I removed it and the brackets it attached to because I want that street look. I swapped out the fuel point with a regular 1x1 blue brick for this reason.&nbsp

column1: The hood and front end is less successful. The hood itself just looks choppy and not aerodynamic at all. It'
column2: s really an eyesore. I had to leave the splitter on as well because without it, the front end looks bad. Oh well.&nbsp

column1: The other drawback to Speed Champions is the plethora of stickers. Ugh. I left almost all of them off, except for the front and rear light assemblies and badges. It'
column2: s frustrating because the set has two printed tiles with &quot
column4: on them. These other pieces could be printed too, but I&#39
column5: m assuming financial reasons preclude that.&nbsp

column2: s a solid Speed Champions set. Find it on sale and add it to your garage.&nbsp

This was a fun Little build the roll cage was an impressive addition.
column2: I really like the Speed Champions 6 stud wide series for its unique and well printed mini figures and build techniques.&nbsp
column3: The side walls for the tyres are an awesome edition and really sets an aggressive stance for the vehicle.

column1: The only con to this set was that it was the only one produced, perhaps if the stickers were on clear film it could'
column2: ve been adapted to other colours.

column1: That being said if you ever see this set still available grab it.

,TRUE,5,5,5,5,5 Green_Bricks","2020-10-06T20:35:23.12Z","Not the (speed) champion of the line, but a solid set nonetheless","

I own quite a few Speed Champions sets, but this one never particularly caught my attention, instead coming into my possession as an impulse buy
column2: I got it for &pound
column4: 12.99, which I thought seemed a good deal. Still, I thought I should review this one, because I always tend to review sets that I think very highly of
column5: maybe I could do with some mediocrity once in a while!

column1: As with all Speed Champions sets, bag 1 is
column2: fairly dull bulking up of the chasis, and bag 2 is constantly interrupted with fiddly stickers! The stickers were predominantly&nbsp
column3: rectangular, so I was able to line them up with other straight lines to make them not look too wonky, but as always, a couple of slip ups are present, although luckily not too noticeable. Overall, I had a fine time building it, and I probably spent about an hour on it, so it was long enough to give me a break from things like homework and revision. However, if given the chance, I probably wouldn&#39
column4: t want to build another one from scratch!

column1: The sets from this range usually look pretty sleek and aesthetically pleasing, and for the most part this one adheres to the rule. I'
column2: m not a fan of the how the windows are blocky in shape towards the back, but I can&#39
column3: t see how the designers would have done a much better job, and for the size of this detail, a rework would hardly be necessary. I just feel in general that there are many edges here that haven&#39
column5: lots of jagged corners and exposed studs make this one feel a bit off. Also, as always, when a detail is split into 2 different stickers, there is a distinctive and unfortunate line down the middle. Overall, I do feel like I&#39
column6: m being a bit harsh on this set, and it looks fine on display, but it does feel like it was quite hastily thrown together, and lacks the premium feel of the McClaren Senna (I don&#39
column7: t know if other people share this opinion, but to me that set is amazing, and&nbsp
column8: my favourite 6 wide car that I own).

column1: I sometimes wonder if anyone really pays attention to the figures in any of these sets! They'
column2: re a nice touch, but I usually don&#39
column3: t think about them when purchasing sets. The driver included here does come with nice back printing featuring the Chevrolet logo, but the torso is the only real part of note
column4: his face is smiling, his helmet is blue, and his legs are white. If you are interested in minifigures, the refuelling tank might be of more interest to you
column5: it comes with a harpoon gun, which could be very useful when included with the summer 2020 ocean subtheme from LEGO City!

column2: 12.99 seems fair for a 198 piece
column4: s a bit more expensive than a LEGO City vehicle of a similar size, but it is definitely more detailed. No complaints here, and the &pound

column1: • Playability - you can put the figure in the driver'
column2: s seat and zoom him around at high speeds. That&#39
column3: s all you can really demand for a set containing one car and one figure. The fuel tank also adds some extra possibilities for story telling. Something like a starting line or speed bumps might have been more useful for a young kid who wanted to set up a racetrack in the living room, but I have no idea what goes into designing these sets, so perhaps that would be too much to ask

column1: • Parts - you get a few nice parts in blue here, such as the 2x2 macaroni tiles, which only appear in 9 other
column2: sets, and the Speed Champions mudguards, which only appear in 3 other sets, all of which are retired. The printed tyres are nice too, although you don&#39
column3: t get any additional accessories such as hubcaps and alternate spoilers that I&#39
column4: ve seen in other sets. Probably not best suited to being a parts pack for the general MOC builder, but if you&#39
column5: re after some specific blue part, this set might just do the trick for it&#39

,TRUE,3,4,3,4,4 fuzthepoet","2020-04-09T02:32:27.32Z","Chevrolet Camaro ZL1 Race Car","

I have bad nerve damage in my hands so my physical therapist recommended Lego'
column2: s as good for fine motor skills practice.

column1: This was my 2nd build. I was to ambiguous with this one. It was a very hard build for me, but I was very proud when I finished. The stickers were by far the worst part. It took my forever to do that part. Overall I was very surprised with the detail of the car.

,TRUE,5,3,4,4,5 kapkap7","2020-04-14T20:26:32.063Z","Great build and fun playset!","

For $14.99, this is an excellent small yet complex build that any Lego fan will enjoy. The pros include a good price/part ratio, an awesome and fun build, and a good amount of playability. The cons include the need to apply dozens of stickers and the inclusion of some highly specialized
column2: parts that might be hard to use in mocs. Overall, this is one of, if not the best Speed Champions set and I would highly recommend buying one.
